The work I’ve made recently, called the Outsider. 
@hayward.gallery  #mystrangeclay
Christmas experiment with material that I had made playfully. Named Outsider @hayward.gallery #mystrangeclay

The Outsider. Made with Clay, Wires and Dried Acrylic paint on the brush. 
@hayward.gallery  #mystrangeclay

How we construct nature around us has been fascinating to me, the forms that follow our collaboration with the nature in order to better our lives. 
For example how we stack up wood, we disconnect them from the land and reconnect them to our lives. Letting the air to travel in between the timbers to dry, placing them in an orderly form so we can build a home for loved ones. Connections and disconnection and eventually reconnections.
I wonder to what extent I am reconnecting to the nature that has provided the materi al to build the home that I’m living now. 
#britishwoodlands #order #contemporaryart #livinigwiththeland
Storm today at the studio, Watching the sound of the wind dance.

Cracks that I make vs the cracks the nature has made. Am I in competition with nature? If we are part of the nature, then our actions are justified? 

#sculpture #contemporaryart #contemporarywoodsculpture #marksofhumanity #natureisnotajoke #care #Oaktree

Connections have become the core of what I do. I stare at connections and joints where they are visible to the eye and see where they lead me and how they are working together.
I wish our connections were also as visible, could look at them and repair them if needed. 

@rcasculpture @royalcollegeofart

The wood always releases pressure through cracks. The pressure that has been under for so many years. A bit of sun always helps. 

#biomimicry #leicaphotography #mentalhealthart #lightislife

Work in progress by @abdollah.nafisi 
The piece that has been inspired by natural cracks of wood in the nature. These cracks happen because of time, age, separation of branches. Tensions that the trees have been under to create a balance with the surroundings. 

@royalcollegeofart @rcasculpture

They shut the road through the woods
Seventy years ago.
Weather and rain have undone it again,
And now you would never know
There was once a road through the woods
Before they planted the trees.

Poem by Rudyard Kipling 

#woodlands #leicaphotography 
#coldbeforethespring #artinforest

The Human experiment 1 by @abdollah.nafisi 
Is a result of a question and an experiment. 
October 2022 when @patriciovillanueva.art paid a visit to Abdollah’s studio, they had a long chat about the latest sculpture of Abdollah’s, and questioned what is the human experience in relation to a hand made sculpture and can sculpture be a mediator meditative tool. It was no time before Patto was sitting on the sculpture and testing if this can be true. Quote” one of the best artistic experiences of my life” Patto said to Abdollah.  Although this was a one off experience, the question remains, 
Can sculpture be a catalyst mediator for a meditative experience? 
“If you are only moved by color relationships, you are missing the point. I am interested in expressing the big emotions - tragedy, ecstasy, doom.”
Mark Rothko 

Size: 210x70x70 cm 

#contemporarysculpture #meditatin #humanexperience

Non of them spoke 
Nor the trees 
Nor the soil 
Nor the frozen frost. 

Abdollah Nafisi
Wind is one of the sources of inspiration for me. Watching it and listening to it

Inside the studio is warm, thinking of a new form whilst hearing the wind through the edges of the door, woo woo. 
Meanwhile thinking of poems 
“A slight wind chafes at the cave mouth, 
I got these woods, their soft iron memory.
Subsoil without me. 
Playing with @seanborodale poetry and making a collage of his writings. 

#abdollahnafisi

Work completed by @abdollah.nafisi made of Hardwood and steel. Ash trees are dying back in the EU and UK as the result of mass deforestation which had broken the echo system of the protective natural forests and the Fungal disease has broken into the protective chain of these species of trees which was in place for thousand of years. 
According to GOV.UK Ash trees make up to 12% of Great Britain.

The piece is made of industrial steel and fell Ash wood. 
Size : 220 x 107 x 77 cm 

#abdollahnafisi

Process shots at the studio. 

@abdollah.nafisi 

Building the piece I’ve now called the bouncer, the work bounces the sound of the viewers voice with a calming meditative bass to the sound. This is a strange direct experience to have with the tree. An experience of gratitude I have in my DNA, always being benefited by the trees. Since childhood I played with sticks under the shade of the trees to this day learning about their properties and how the civilisations Can learn from them. So why not speaking with the piece?
In order to achieve this reflection of sound I dried the wood to act like an instrument, this process took 2 years keeping the sculpture in dry conditions. 

#contemporarysculpture #leicaphotography

I want to thank you all for supporting my journey. 
Many of you came to the shows that I’ve been part of recently and many of you collaborated with me in multiple projects. I’m grateful for it all. 
June is the studio month for me and will be sharing with you the process of my work and also the exhibitions that I’ve had the pleasure to be part of.

The new piece I’m working on is the story of pulling out what hurts and digging into where I find meaning. 
The story of Removing and Replacing.
The trees have been our most loyal friends and the ones that have helped us the most to survive. 
Yet they are the most silent and humble ones. 

The truth is that we are not more powerful than the trees! They can release a pollen and job done. For some reason they are still patient. 
I am going to dedicate the next 5 years of my practice to learn from these species and share with you. I will works with them and learn from them. 
Stay with me in this journey.

Circles and horizontal and vertical lines have become a focal point of focus for me. Since 2021. The root of using circle in both western and Islamic architecture has been about power. This power does not indicate a military or political power, how ever it has been used for its function. The attention and focus that circles can bring in their geometrical form. A line with no end, no meaning but yet containing focus which can link to spiritual power. I see circles as tools , as portals as a tool for meditation. 
I’m looking back into a work I make in early 2022 and seeing all the links of this work to Islamic architecture I went to visit as a child with my mother for her MA architectural projects. 
I will tell you the stories as I’m time they reveal back to me along my research.

A one page sculpture project on the theme of Strike made by @abdollah.nafisi published by @formaartsmedia along with 57  artists to contribute to a low of zine publication by Forma inspired by DIY publishing and deconstructed book making. 
58 artists invited to respond to the title STRIKE, exploring action as political intent, as performative happening, and gusty rap act of taking pen to page. Acting as an anti book, this handmade publication aims to reverse the usual restrictions that can limit access to publishing and gives access to artists an opportunity to share their work, knowledge and ideologies.

Sculpture painting by @abdollah.nafisi 
From the ‘mirage’ series, Abrah honours the narrow streams of water found in the desert- the space of no limits, which imbues those who gaze upon it with a unique sense of well-being and patience. 

Inscribed on the back is a poem by Abdollah. Intentionally inaccessible by virtue of being on the rear side of the artwork, these words call to be committed to memory, and passed down through repetition and storytelling, as words have always been to the people of the desert lands. 

Walked long paths to find the water
Looked
Gazed
Long
Gazed long to see the blue

Rebirth by @abdollah.nafisi 

Oak and Brass
161 x 28 x 28 cm 2022
Made of Oak from one of the 9 million trees felled during the 1987 storm in the UK, and brass cast from steam bent, twisted pieces of UK Ash, Re Birth is inspired by the Dotar, the Persian instrument through which the parallel stories of humanity and nature are told. The wood has been charred and polished fifty times with natural oil to draw out the pigments

Born In Tehran, @abdollah.nafisi lives and works in the UK, using organic materials to create improvised sculptures.
With a background in Japanese woodwork, Abdollah uses locally sourced wood as his primary material, viewing the wood as a storyteller of time.
On this basis of objecthood, he examines issues of heritage and temporality with elements such as fire and metal.
During his travels with nomads and tribes of Iran, learning mystical Sufi music and studying the Persian kilim carpet, he explored the contemporary meaning of connection between humanity and nature. This became a portal through which to explore the parallel ecologies of human life and his local woodland.
Resting between a utopian and dystopian vision, Abdollah’s work explores the tensions of our current times and opens up a dialogue about creativity, technology and connectivity with the land.

Sculpture made by @abdollah.nafisi called “Panj” is made of Oak by , Ash and steel, burnt by fire and bent with steam. It is inspired by the Dotar, the Persian instrument played by Abdollah which is a primary tool for the storytelling of Sufi and Persian poetry. The industrial bolts that fuse the two elements of the piece speak to both connection and separation. 

#contemporaryart #contemporarysculpture  #dotar

@annelyjuda 𝘎𝘢𝘵𝘩𝘦𝘳 𝘵𝘰 𝘓𝘰𝘰𝘴𝘦 opens this Thursday 6-8pm. A group exhibition exploring a shared concern with material, natural or manmade, and it’s relationship to sustainability.

Introducing - Abdollah Nafisi

Born in Tehran @abdollah.nafisi spent several years traveling with Iran’s nomadic tribes, immersing himself in their craft legacy and studying the improvisation techniques of the handmade rugs and kilims created in direct response to their landscape. 

Predominantly made from rescued local wood, Nafisi’s sculptures explore themes of heritage and temporality. Honouring the process of spontaneity, he examines the parallel ecologies of nature and of man, reflecting on our moments of connection and dis-connection. His latest practice explores the creation of a new hybrid language that utilises sound and performance to further delve into the concept of inter-connectivity.

Nafisi graduates from the Royal College of Art @rcasculpture this year and his degree show will run 13 - 16 July @trumanbrewery

Image: The Bouncer, 2023, burnt Oak wood, paint and steel. 202 x 110 x 80 cm

#GatherToLoose #AnnelyJuda #abdollahnafisi #Upcoming  #GroupShow #LondonExhibibition #FreeLondon #Sustainability #Climate #woodensculpture #soundart #bouncer

Final body of works by @abdollah.nafisi  exhibited at graduation show 2022-2023 program @royalcollegeofart Truman brewery. 

Lives and works in the UK Abdollah is Originally from Iran. He travelled the deserts of Iran/Persia for six years alongside nomads and tribes, observing their response to the land. There he learnt the art of improvisation, his works aim to translate this sense of embodiment through emergent methods of form making that explore the essence of ‘connectivity’.

I've had the honour to be exhibiting two of my works at @annelyjuda, along side some of the legendary artists that have made a significant mark in the history of #modernart and #contemporaryart.
Tomorrow 25th of August is the last day to visit the show. 

#annelyjudafineart #abdollahnafisi 
#davidnash #tadashikawamata #rogerackling

The work Vulnerability @annelyjuda, placed right next to #rogerackling. 
The last day to visit the show.

Two of my works were exhibited @annelyjuda Summer group show 2023, it was a great honour for me to place my works in the gallery where has dovetailed some of the most significant historical events in the history of Contemporary Art. 

My special thanks to my Tutors at @royalcollegeofart @rcasculpture 
who helped me patiently to develop my research and practice:

@mssonyadyer @jasparjosephlester @headhearthole @__sarah__staton__ @denisedecordova1 @grahamhuds0n #seanashton @melanie.jjj 

I want to humbly thank those of you who visited the show, supported, mentored, guided and considered writing about the works. 
@londonartcritic @osmanstudio @rachelbungey @pssa_sculpture @valimahlouji @jessmunck @picturesofthingsdotcom @seanborodale @mamali_shafahi @formaartsmedia @jihantahri and many more. 
Some more and some less, I am very grateful of universe to be placed on this path with you.

With the legend @shirin__neshat at @goodman_gallery

#shirinneshat

Panj in Farsi means number 5. This will be a body of 5 pieces ۵ 
 
Pieces are made of wood from English woodlands and Brass. 
Burn by Fire and bent by Steam. 
It has been inspired by the instrument I play Dotar. Capturing and imaginative form of sound as a tool for telling stories.
The industrial Bolts and the turned Brass fuse the two elements of the piece, Speak of both connection and separation. 

Mirage Series 
Ash And Oak 
Finished with Shou Sugi Ban Technique 

2023
